review_title: Too Fat, Too Slow, and Too Dumb
pros: Great compensation and 401k plan. Very easy to hide and keep your head down.
cons:
WestRock is the prime example of a company that can't get out of its own way. 

The company is way too FAT with too many levels. I worked at corporate and I worked in the field and I can say I honestly wondered what some people did for 40 hours a week - but those people were always the one impeding change or progress forward. They could make a 30% cut at corporate and never notice those people missing - I am being serious!

WestRock and the industry in general have been slow to move into a digital economy, especially when it comes to going to market. It's tough to make change in a large global company, but middle and upper management resist doing anything different than they did 25 years ago. I was amazed at how stagnant this company is, especially for being a Fortune 200. If you join the company don't expect to be working on the cutting edge of anything. Ask yourself, If I left this job in X number of years what have I learned that I can go do somewhere else? There's a reason people stay in the industry all their life, they don't get applicable skills to do anything else.

Change and forward progress is always welcomed with skepticism, and if you make your boss or senior management feel threatened by your potential - go ahead and pack it up because they only want yes people who agree with their ideas. And trust me, there are plenty of bad ideas to go around here. They're currently trying to change the culture in the company by putting a premium on bringing in more diversity. Why not just hire better people regardless of what they look like?

If you want to meek out a paycheck and a long career never pushing yourself or learning anything new - this is the company to do it at. HR is so terrified of a lawsuit they rarely will fire people, and believe me I've seen some pretty awful behavior at every level of the company that was tolerated.

The packaging industry is primed for disruption. I have seen every single exciting new innovative product fail because you do sales and marketing as it was done in 1995. We're moving into 2020, you should act like you live in that time too.

Do a better job of identifying toxic managers. Employees shuffle in and out but toxic managers stay the same, you should always want to see someone under you succeed higher than you - not keep them down.

cons:
WestRock, used to be a 25,000 person company. It is now a 50,000 person company as a result of a series of acquisitions.
But getting bigger did not make the company more profitable. Instead, it increased corporate debt, brought the scrutiny of government regulators, and left management trying to piece together a confused mess of mills and corporate structures and ex-headquarters and workforces The result -- significant white collar layoffs at the Atlanta Headquarters and in the plants that started October 1, and aren't likely to end anytime soon. 
A company facing this is a bad place to be. People are stressed, worried about the future and face doing much more with less. Layoff decisions are arbitrary and often appear mean-spirited. WestRock’s severance model is 1 week for each year of employment and uses Sub-Pay, a perfectly legal but definitely punitive method, to reduce severance payments. Sub-Pay requires employees to file for unemployment immediately after leaving the company in order to get their severance. Then deducts from the weekly severance the weekly amount of unemployment. This affects everyone – except of course the C-suite.
WestRock’s compensation levels are below industry standard. They won’t increase much (if at all) while you are there. Their corporate structure is flat and stove piped and WestRock corporate doesn’t promote people. The average raise (when one is given) is 1 or 2 percent. HR is focusing on luring millennials to the company. Given these realities, that group won’t be happy or interested, even if there is a ping pong table in the lunchroom.
The current CHRO has been around for a couple of years. She often challenges old ways (sometimes a good thing), but the CHRO approach to people management is defined by this statement made in her opening remarks at the company: “A meeting with me is a learning experience”. That attitude trickles down.
